description: From Middle English ruddocke, ruddok, roddok, from Old English rudduc, ruduc (“robin, ruddock”, literally “little red one, red-ling”), equivalent to rud (“redness”) +‎ -ock (diminutive suffix). The Welsh rhuddog, and Cornish rudhek (“the redbreast”) are probably from the English, although a derivation from a British Celtic *roudākos (< *roudos "red") for all three cannot be ruled out. More at rud.

examples: The tame ruddock and the coward kite.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A piece of gold money (probably because the gold of coins was often reddened by copper alloy).
examples: Great pieces of gold  […]  red ruddocks.
